value.title: Understanding data lineage in DAX

value.title: Using ALLEXCEPT vs ALL VALUES
value.excerpt: ALLEXCEPT is a handy DAX function to retrieve all the columns of a table except for some. When used as a CALCULATE modifier, its behavior is less intuitive and might result in inaccurate measures. In this video, we elaborate on the most common mistake when using ALLEXCEPT in CALCULATE. Article and download:

value.title: Using USERELATIONSHIP in DAX
value.excerpt: This video shows how to use the USERELATIONSHIP function in DAX to change the active relationship in a CALCULATE function. Article and download: https://sql.bi/664175

value.title: Write DAX formulas for Power BI Desktop models
value.excerpt: In this module, you'll learn how to write DAX formulas to create calculated tables, calculated columns, and measures, which are different types of model calculations. Additionally, you'll learn how to write and format DAX formulas, which consist of expressions that use functions, operators, references to model objects, constants, and variables.

value.title: Introduction to modern analytics using Excel and Power BI
value.excerpt: This module introduces the Microsoft modern analytics core suite of tools, including Office 365/Excel 2016+, Power Query, Data Model, Power BI Desktop, and Power BI service. By using modern analytics technologies, you and your organization can work faster, more efficiently, and smarter by using Excel together with Power BI.

value.title: Statistics and Correlation Tables in Power BI with Python
value.excerpt: Learn how to build summary statistics tables that have min, max, quartiles, standard deviation and mode and counts in one tables. value.title: DAX Fridays! #14: SUMMARIZE
value.excerpt: Learn how to use the function SUMMARIZE in DAX/ Powerpivot.  The function SUMMARIZE can return a summary of sales grouped around the calendar year and the product category name, this result table allows you to do analysis over the reseller sales by year and product category.  Source:https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg492171.aspx

value.title: DAX Fridays! #21: USERELATIONSHIP
value.excerpt: A common example in a Power BI table is to have multiple dates, which are related to the same Date table. As you are limited to one active relationship, we need to use the DAX function USERELATIONSHIP to manage the inactive relationships.  Link to Power BI file: https://curbal.com/blog/glossary/userelationship-dax
